Review: I am pushing 30's but I still love Harry potter like I did when I was a teenager and today I gave it as a gift to a teenager who is new to the book world. The books arrived in a perfect condition, timely delivery, well packed and along with a book mark. None of pages are missing and the paper quality is too good no speck of yellow is seen even the print is good. The conversation carried out between Ron Hermione and Harry through letters are printed in different fonts and the rest in different which gives the whole book an interesting look. The new readers can feel the conversation actually happening in their mind like a play on radio.

Review title: And the magical journey begins AGAIN
Review: Having finished the UK version years ago, and to quench the desire to start all over again led me to buy this edition. Nominal changes in otherwise known story makes the journey a bit more interesting. Since the content of the book is already known to many, I am strictly sticking to the condition and quality of the book.The book was delivered to me in excellent condition, this version is a bit bigger and thicker than the Bloomsbury UK edition, and due to increased real estate of the book, contents of the pages seem a bit less congested. If you‚Äôre someone who loves a bit large and thick book in their hands go for the US edition instead of the UK one. Chapters too start with a small cartoon which is a nice touch. As can be noticed in the pictures provided  pages are a bit bright than UK one but truth be told might be because of the fact that the UK edition is with me for quite some time.Highly recommended‚Ä¶.

It is the first book in the Harry Potter series. I know, everybody love Harry Potter and here I am reviewing it anyway.LIKES: üòäüòä1) World Formation: The whole world building is mind-boggling. The wizarding world is very vast and intricately woven as it has witches, wizards, goblins, three-headed dog, dragon, centaurs, unicorns, and whatnot.2) Characterization: All the characters have been well thought out. No character looked like it's only there as a page filler. The book is full of variety of characters from kind-hearted to mean bullies. Step by step building of friendship between the trio (Harry, Ron and Hermione) is just a sight to behold. The unfolding of characters such as Hermione (from bossy know-it-all to a kind soul who acknowledges the efforts of others) and Neville (who being scardy cat all the time, summons up the courage to take a stand against Draco's minions as well as his friends) is inexplicable and neatly done.3) Writing: J.K. Rowling's writing is so vivid that you will wish you were a witch or wizard, too! Writing is simple which makes it easier to dive into. I love all the positivity spreading through her unique writing style and messages. Dersley family's characters is so well written that everyone abhor them to the core.4) Plot: Plot is very unique and intriguing with fast-paced and gripping story. A great plot twist at the end is an add-on bonus. The clues are nicely linked with the each other and very detailed as compared to the movies.DISLIKES: üòíüòí1)¬†I already watched all the movies before the book. Big mistake. So, plot twist at the end was a dead giveaway for me.2) The book is very similar to the movie, so i didn't get to enjoy as much as i should've. Totally my fault!Despite devouring the Harry Potter movie, i loved the book all the same. I recommend it to all the fantasy lovers out there. No matter what age group you belong to, this series is perfect for you. Highly recommended! üòäüôè

Review title: Very bad service by Amazing Buy

The book quality is very good, even the pages are in a good condition, the name 'Harry Potter and The philosopher's stone' is named in golden shine, surrounded by golden shiny stars and the cover illustration of the book is nice, Moreover, there are no stains, no fading of the golden shine of the cover text, the pages were not torn neither folded. The book was delivered nicely. But Amazon should start giving bookmarks also, which is important accessory for readers. The book is really interesting, and I was really impressed by the book quality... I have done reading it, it is so nice book for most of the ages. Still it's been almost a month, and it is still looking beautiful. Thank you Amazon for the book at its bestest conditions, but please provide bookmarksüîñ also.Harry potter series is a 7 book series ,of Harry and his friend's adventures.A giant man comes to Harry's uncle's home, after thousand letters to him(which they burn) and says he is a wizard. Should Harry believe him? Shall Harry potter continue to be a wizard? He explores the wizarding world and finds out he is very popular, and is called as The Boy who lived. Why is he popular? Who he is? What is his history?He has a adventurous first year, and also suspects that one of the teachers is after some important thing, which is guarded by a monstrous three headed dog. Harry has to save the thing. Can Harry and his friends save the thing? And why is the person after the thing?Read on to find out.

HARRY POTTER. WHAT CAN BE MORE WONDERFUL THAN THIS WHOLE SERIES.... J.K ROWLING IS ONE OF THE MOST WELL KNOWN AUTHORS. THIS SERIES OF BOOKS WRITTEN BY HER MADE ME A BOOKWORM. I DID NOT WANT TO DO ANYTHING ELSE OTHER THAN READ AFTER READING THE FIRST BOOK . I HAVE ALREADY READ THIS SERIES OF BOOKS AND AFTER READING THEM I FELT LIKE READING IT AGAIN SO THIS IS THE SECOND TIME . BEING A POTTERHEAD PEOPLE IN SCHOOL ALSO CALL ME POTTER. THIS SERIES OF BOOKS IS FOR ALL AGES AND EVERYONE IS FREE TO READ IT.THIS MYSTERY,THIRLLER AND COMEDY MAKES ME WANNA ACTUALLY BE IN THE PLACE OF HARRY AND IMAGINE WHAT I WOULD DO. IT ALSO BUILDS UP MY CONFIDENCE TO FACE AND CONQUER DIFFICULTIES IN MY LIFE. IT ALSO TEACHES ME THAT HARDWORK IS THE KEY TO SUCCESS .  ANVEE SONTAKKE ....

I am so glad I read this book. I would definitely have missed something if I hadn't picked this up. Such a gem of a book. The writing is so enormously beautiful. You literally imagine all the vivid details. The writing is so lucid and entertaining that you cant stop yourself from reading the book in one go. (But I didnt..) I think I read it in five or six sittings deliberately so I couldn't get over enjoying myself. Such a page turner and such a warm hearted story.You root for Harry throughout. You feel for the characters. A well executed plot. I can go on raving about this book but let me stop and yes, I will be buying the second part soon.

Harry Potter is my favorite book series ever. The movie adaptations are also quite good. I have read all the books before but buying it once again because of the new book covers. Keeping the story aside, the new cover arts are amazing.Story:I am probably reading Philosopher's Stone for the 4th time and every time I read, I discover new hidden secrets just like harry discovers many secrets about Hogwarts in his first year. JK Rowling is probably one of my favorite female author. The way she has engineered the stories is just brilliant. I also love the way she introduces the new characters to us, its ingenious. If you are someone who haven't read any one the Harry Potter books, then I will highly suggest to start with this book, taking in account that you love to read and explore new kingdoms. Not going deep into the story because you can already read the synopsis in this very page. If you have seen the movie first then reading this book, then you will get to know a ton of new plots but if you are planning to do the opposite, then be prepared to be somewhat disappointed. Nevertheless, Happy Reading.About the book and delivery:- The book was delivered on time.- The condition of the book was perfect, no torn pages.- I was expecting a bookmark from Amazon but was disappointed.- I will suggest to wait for a book sale because I got a 48% discount on this book.

‚ùùThis boy will be famous. There won't be a child in our world who doesn't know his name.‚ùûEveryone grew up with Harry Potter. They read all the books when they were young and watched all the films. They would re-watch and re-read them. They would fall in love with the Wizarding World and would completely adore Harry, Ron, and Hermione. They would talk about them non stop, about Hogwarts, about its teachings, about them wanting to become students there and pretending they are, about joining the HP fandom, about loving every character and instantly missing the world. Everyone would adore Harry Potter and knew about it since they were young ones.Except me.Ex claimer-BASED ON A TRUE STORY.I didn't grow up with Harry Potter. Not because I didn't get to, but because I chose not to. I know, it's like living a life where everything has been a lie. Worse even. It's just, the movies would appear on my tv. From the first one, to the next and the next, and every time I saw the trailer for the upcoming one, I wouldn't be interested and would skip it when I came to it. I wouldn't bother and wouldn't care, and that made a big problem in my life now. Here I am now, being left out because of such poor choices and decisions I made when I was 7, 8, 9, and older until now. But now, as 2016 and having over 100 friends that are caught up and have read the recently published novel, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, I have finally read the first book and am able to continue the series and watch the films. Now, here I am, wishing to go back to my past and change this nightmare and actually watch the films or read the books because I have literally missed on so much, missed too much, and have been missing too much. I have been out of this world and never realized how good it is, and how special it already has become."There is no good and evil, there is only power, and those too weak to seek it."All the first timers ORDER now and finish it."Petrificus Totalus"~Search It

I don't think I need to write a lot, because Harry Potter is self explanatory. The plots, characters, timing, dialogue, and everything else is beyond brilliant. Don't think, just go for it. However, if you're a person like me, who lives for pretty covers, I suggest that you buy the Children's covers, which are livelier and more attractive.

Neither he knows that his parents too were great witch and wizard. A welcome guest in the form of rubeus hagrid revels harry's true identity to him and that he is to go to hogwarts school of witchcraft and wizardry. Review title: Breathtakingly stunning edition of the well loved 1st book of the Harry Potter series!!!!!
Review: A gorgeous edition for collectors and fans alike, this deluxe version of the illustrated harry potter and the philosopher's stone is simply stunning. With sophisticated line art by Jim Kay on the purple cloth covered slipcase and the book itself, this is definitely something to treasure for a lifetime! The book itself is very heavy and large with high quality premium grade paper and gilt edges , accompanied by a huge diagon alley poster. Of course the book is a little expensive but I'm damn sure that it's worth each and every penny. Simply awesome. Just go for it.

Late into the night at a stay over my friends house, completely devoid of sleep, I somehow muttered a meek promise to my friend. One to give Potter a try. Thank heavens, I did! It doesn't matter whether you're a 6 year old or in your twenties, J.K. Rowling opens a whole newworld of magic and takes you on a ride you'd be happy to hop on! And once you finish reading this absolutely-fantastic book, you can't wait to get your hands on the next part!

Review title: Would you judge and review bible?
Review: Alright gather around!!! Collect your tickets here for we have for you an amazing persona who has not read Harry potter in her life and yes that person would be me.Yeah yeah I know that I have to have been living under a rock to have not read this book yet. But at least I was aware of the series. So why finally read it?a)One of my book soul mate have been practically begging me to do sob)Let‚Äôs just say that there is this one person who may have not even bothered to read a shopping receipt in her life, let alone a book. So turns out that even this person has read harry potter series and even have all the seven books in her collection and when that person mocks you about having not read Harry potter, then you know things have gone bad and that you are doomed and you should pile up on the potter series as fast as you can, so that you could shut the person up.You should know about me that my room has furniture made out of books because that‚Äôs how massive my collection and addiction to books is and apparently none of them is a harry potter book. Apparently not having read a Harry potter book makes me some kind of outlaw and sinner in the book world so fearing the wrath of book gods, I have finally read my first harry potter book. (so open up the best bottle in your collection and we will have party at your house)So leaving all the crap aside‚Ä¶let‚Äôs talk about the bookThere is practically nothing that you can say that has not been said before. Yes the book is intriguing, grasping and full of fun element. It is something that any age can immerse themselves into without regrets. No doubt I want to go through the entire series. There are elements and magic world details that need your undivided attention. In whole, the book is pretty good and one hell of a read.

Review title: a letter to muggles who have put the one star.
Review: i am writting this letter to rhe people who have put one star. when people look or read reviews they always look out for one star rating reviews. i have done it myself. most of the reviews are stating that their hard copy is in an abysmal condition.well, to solve that problem follw these simple steps.1. downlaod the amazon kindle app2. make yourselves an account.3. buy your desired book.it comes as a soft copy. this might be a setback but there are two advantages.1. it comes in an amazing condition2. you can edit it to your liking.3. it comes in half the price. so again, there is a solution to your problem. or just call up amazon and ask for a better version.with regards-Albus Dumbeldore.:)-

Review title: Now after I finished the book I just realised that the guy who reviewed the book was completely wrong I found the book very easy
Review: I am a 13 year old boy and at first I thought that this book was not for my age when I read one of the reviews. But still I ignored it and I bought the book. Now after I finished the book I just realised that the guy who reviewed the book was completely wrong I found the book very easy to read even an 10 year old could understand it.Anyways the book was very nice and interesting and made me purchase the Harry Potter and the chamber of secrets. The book delivery was very fast I got it the very next day.the cover of the book was very smooth and it is the best quality cover for books. The book also contains an awesome bookmark.thank you Amazon and thank you jk.Rowling

Do not get me wrong. There is no substitute to Harry Potter books. The quality of this particular edition is excellent as well. But the cost simply does not justify the end product. there are NO extra artworks above the normal illustrated version and except for a poster of diagon alley (which I am SURE u can get printed for a fraction of the cost of the book), there is nothing extra in the deluxe edition. Adding the fact that the illustrated version has the same dimensions and costs a 20th the price of the deluxe edition, the price tag cannot be justified at all. Even as a collector, I would say that the publishers could have at least included an autograph of the author herself.Sorry, but I really cannot justify the costs. The story and the artwork deserve 5 stars themselves of course

Review title: A epic journey into a magical world
Review: I choose this rating because I don't want to give it 5 stars, since this is the first ever novel I have read and it just wouldn't be fair to say that this is the best novel I have ever read.But at the same I don't wanna give it less than 4 stars because this is the first time I have ever read a novel and it kept me engaged even though I have watched the movies.The things I like about this book is that it answers many questions which is hard to think of when you are watching a movie and there is more in the book than it is in the movie.The thing I disliked about this book is that it is a little hard to understand some words but since this is my first ever novel I have read this problem has got to do with me more than it has got to do with the book also the way hagrid speaks is a little hard to understand.At last I would recommend this book to the people who loves reading novels about fantasies, supernatural, and magical worlds and the people who have watched the Harry Potter movies but have not read the books, it helps to see the story in a different way and angle, also there is a lot more here than it is in the movie.

Review title: Pick It Up Irrespective Of Your Age
Review: I never thought that I would be giving 5 stars to a kid's fantasy series. Primarily a non-fiction reader, I decided to read something light in fiction and with up the first book of the Harry Potter Series. Picked it thinking to give a shot on the much talked about best in fiction, so what if its from the kid's section.Today when I finish this book, I am astonished by the impact it has left after the last chapter. Once you get the hang of Hogwarts there is no looking back. You just keep sinking into it and start visualizing every nuance of Rowling's fantasy world.The story weaves humour, friendship, bravery, courage all into a magical world which doesn't leave you. Even after the book ends, you are left curious and longing to pick the next book.

Plot: Harry Potter is an orphan, mistreaded by his aunt and unce, Mr and Mrs Dursley and constantly being bullied by his cousin Dudley. However, he always makes inexplicable things happening around him, and gets punished for them. All of this is explained when Hagrid explains that Harry is a wizard, and sens him to a magical school, Hogwarts. There he is famous and makes many friends, and two for life: Ron Weasely and Hermione Granger.With the help of magical wit, guidance of his friends, and by stumbling across things by sheer coincidence, Harry has to solve mysteries.The villian, Lord Voldemort had been destroyed years ago due to some unknown power possessed by Harry, and haunts Harry's first year to seek revenge.Harry has to stop him, and has to save Hogwarts.Review: Harry Potter is one of the magical epics of the world. J.K Rowling, with those bewitching and enchanting words of her, has really taken the characters we use to hear in Fairy Tales to a next level.The language is lucid, but the plot is riveting and evocative. There are jerks and twists along the story. One minute you read,'No more dragon -- Malfoy in detention -- what could spoil their happiness?'And the next.'The answer was waiting at the fot of the stairs...they had left the Invisibility Cloak at the top of the tower.'She has created a world that co-exists with our own, which is what makes the story so believable.It it also easy to connect with, because it also has things and places that we normally do; a bank(Gringotts), a school(Hogwarts), a government(Ministry of Magic) and even Shopping Alleys!It also faces real-life problems, like being under the pressure of entering a new school in a young age, not being able to complete homework, getting selected in sports teams, going through detentions, sneaking things out of school and so on, even though they are magical, which helps us to connect with characters.In Toto, you will find that you simply can't keep the book down till you devour each word of it. It really is really the book that defines the magical zeitgeist.

Review title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
Review: I really enjoyed reading this book, it's about a boy who lives in the broom closet in his uncles house who manages to make it to Hogwarts, a school for wizards and witches. This book is one of those books that gets the plot stuck in my head and then I walk around all day thinking about it. If you're thinking about getting only one book in the series, this book is going to leave you in suspense. So this all in all a wonderful book that I think anyone will love. People who crave fantasy, this is all for you.

I started reading Harry Potter books to know more about the serious events that takes places from the 5th movie onwards, after everyone has grown up (the 3rd one being an exception, I loved Prisoner of Azkaban). First four books are more like what I have to get done with, to begin the fifth (when everything suddenly becomes dark). I didn't thought I'd enjoy the beginning ones this much, but this book was really a lot better than what I expected. Few things I like more in the book than the movies, and similarly, few things I like in the movies more. But if liked the first book (in which all our protagonists are just kids), I'm pretty sure I'll enjoy the next books in the series as well.

BOOK REVIEW: HARRY POTTER AND THE PHILOSOPHER'S STONEName of book: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's stoneAuthor : JK RowlingPublications: BloomsburyNo. Of pages: 332Cost of book: 399 INRGenre : Fantasy fictionHarry potter is undoubtedly one of the most unprecedented and appreciated books of all times. This book , within two decades has received immense love and appreciation from 'potterheads' worldwide. The fame received by this book is uncommon due to the vast majority of people liking the book. Written by JK Rowling,  this book has sold over 48 million copies and has been a fan favourite since it was first published.The book is in form of narrative with its genre catering to people who like fantasy fiction.The book opens in number 4 , Privet Drive and introduced is ' the boy who lived' , Harry Potter, who has to deal with a miserable life of living in a storeroom, using glasses stuck  with scotch tape and going through his share of ordeal by being constantly bullied by his cousin , Dudely.But his life takes a complete turn when mysterious letters start coming to his 'house'. Initially reluctant to read those letters , his relatives have to read the letters when a genial half giant , called Rubeus Hagrid , comes to his house with an invitation of studying magic at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.It is then revealed that Harry Potter's parents were murdered by Voldermort and Harry , miraculously survived Voldermort's attack , bearing only a lightning bolt scar on his forehead.And then starts Harry's magical journey in Hogwarts.  He makes friends , fights bullies , learns about the fantastic game of Quidditch and most importantly  uncovers the secret behind the PHILOSOPHER'S STONE.The book has been written ensuring that it does not go out of place with young readers and thus has included everyday situations so that the book is more approachable to tweens. Harry is very much like all of us- confused yet courageous.The twists and turns in the book keep the readers glued to the book and the narration is fabulously done. The language is lucid and the vocabulary has been wisely chosen. The loose ends of the book are tied with expertise as more threads become compellingly unravelled.This book is a souvenir in English literature and is a paragon of the 21st century literature,  which is suitable for all age groups, be it young adults, children and even adults!Taking my opinion,  this book surely deserves a try and is going to stay with you forever as you embark on the magical journey with Harry and his friends.

Review title: I JUST WISH I COULD WAVE MY WAND AND TRANSPORT MYSELF INTO THE HARRY POTTER  UNIVERSE
Review: Being a book lover myself I can happily say that this according to me IS THE BEST SERIES OF BOOKS EVER WRITTEN . I can still remember thet my father always told me that I must read Harry Potter ,but I never listened to him .Then finally one day I decided to go and buy the first book (philosopher's stone ) . I remember going from bookstore to bookstore not being able to find it. Then ... FINALLY  I found it . That day when I came back home I read for five hours straight no break and finished it , my first thought after I read this book was that why did I not listen to my father?.The thing that I enjoyed most about this book and series is that it can be read by all ages you don't have to be a kid to read the Harry Potter series you could even be 81 and still read this book without saying "oh it's too kiddish".. I also enjoy the friendship between Ron ,Harry and Hermione and how they all stand up for each other and protect them from harm ..J.K. Rowling has also added many quotes inside this book spoken by various characters ,some that have a deepmeaning that needs to be understood . for example"LIGHT CAN BE FOUND EVEN IN THE MOST DARKEST OF PLACES IF ONLY ONE REMEMBERS TO SWITCH ON THE LIGHT "and some which simply say what they mean . For example"WE ALL HAVE GOOD AND BAD INSIDE OF US . BUT WHAT MATTERS IS PART WE CHOOSE TO ACT ON".to end this review all I can say is thatthank you J.K. Rowling for introducing me to the wizarding world which will always have a special place in my heart.

Review title: THE BEST FANTASY OF THE WORLD
Review: Life can turn a person's tables upside-down suddenly; it could be bad or it could be good. This is what happens with Harry Potter: the boy who lived. Goodness is always paid in life in one form or the other and after ten long years of TORTURE, Harry potter's goodness pays off. He enters a new world, a world where magic dominates over everything and to his utter surprise Harry is famous out there instead of being called a dumb because he knows nothing about magic. In his first year at Hogwarts, Harry crosses all the obstacles with sheer courage and bravery. A salute to J.K. Rowling for her undefeatable imagination. The book was interesting from the starting till it ended and that is for what I liked it the most. After reading this book, I am sure that if a reader has not read Harry Potter, he hasn't entered the literary world.

Review title: High cost for poor quality paper.  Search for other publications
Review: Most of the reviews mentioned here are for the Harry Potter story and not for the book quality. I ordered library binding for my neice, as it was her first Harry Potter book. So I read it for the 16th time as per goodreads and I still do not dare to review it. I mean it's as difficult as measuring your closest friend or any loved one on the parameters of good and bad. Surely they will have both the qualities but you purposefully choose to overlook not so good ones because of the love you have for them. Same is the case with this book, I have lived a life with the boy who lived and the other characters of this series. All these characters are as much my friend (or enemy) as anyone in flesh and blood. Since this book was the beginning of it all, it holds an important place in my little library and heart as well. Probably this is the reason I have 5 different editions of this book :)Right from that "dull, gray Tuesday when our story starts" till the time harry decided "to have a lot of fun with Dudley in summer holidays" every single line is just perfect; and people who thinks that this is a story for kids or watching the movie is enough well! they couldn't be more wrong. It's been more than a decade since I read it first and still I haven't found any book or series who has as much of impact on me as this one had; and the best thing is that no matter how many times have you read them before you just can't help it to fall in love with JKR's world and characters all over again. She literally has created MAGIC with this and missing something as good as this is a crime.

Review title: Ms. JK Rowling ‚Äì thank you for weaving magic!
Review: I fell in love with Harry Potter the first time I read this book ‚Äì some time in 1999, I think. And all that magic surrounding him ‚Äì I just lapped it all up. The characters that pop out of the book and dance in front of one‚Äôs eyes as you read the words is nothing short of amazing ‚Äì I got transported into a different realm. Ron, Hermione, Hagrid, Neville, Dumbledore, Malfoy, Snape and most important of all ‚Äì you-know-who ‚Äì what kind of research and imagination must have come together to create these!  I hated the Dursleys more than Harry did ‚Äì Vernon, Petunia and Dudley. I loved talking to the snake through Harry and felt thrilled when it got its freedom. I got quite excited when Harry found out that he was a wizard and got a chance to go to Hogwarts. I was thrilled with every single adventure that Harry underwent at the tender age of eleven ‚Äì feeling sad for his losses and mistreatment while feeling envious about the magic he was connected to. I hated Snape and Malfoy and wanted to hit out at them on Harry‚Äôs behalf.  Every time Harry lifted his wand to perform a spell, I could feel my right hand twitching. I have lived and breathed Harry Potter and can‚Äôt have enough of him.  The magic spells, Hogwarts' Express, 9 3/4 Platform, the invisibility cloak, the Mirror of Erised, the moving photographs, the magical staircases and corridors, the paintings, the ghosts, parsel-tongue, muggles ‚Äì give me more, please!  How can I forget Quiddich? Such a complicated game and described so clearly and precisely. It was such a thrill when Harry becomes the youngest seeker. I soared on the broom every time Harry took off in it.  I just loved every aspect of the book and each time I read it ‚Äì it takes me a couple of weeks to recover from the fantasy world and get back to normal.  Ms. JK Rowling ‚Äì thank you for weaving magic!

This was a repurchase for me as my original Harry Potter book is battered from years of reading. I've reread this book since and of course, I loved it. The beginning can be a little slow for younger readers as a lot of it is not in the movies, but the remaining 85% is and can be completely imagined throughout. I like the fact most of the original dialogue was translated into movies which is something I've noticed since rereading as an adult. Lovely start to the fabulous series and I am buying the full set to have a newer looking set on my shelf!The artwork on the cover is so much better than the original book which is red. There are illustrations around the chapter headings too which adds a special something. The paper in this book is a lot firmer and of better quality. It's bigger in length than my original one by about 100 pages but that's probably just a printing difference. There isn't anything additional. I think there was a map in the front of mine but I 'm unsure.Fab read of course.

Review title: Review H.P. ?  -  I can't do that!
Review: My Granddaughter has been asking me for my copy of Harry Potter Book 1, but I know my daughter only too well and I know if my copy goes to their house, in all likelihood it won't be back into mine, hence the purchase! I'm sure H.P. doesn't need a review by me, just to say that children need magic in their lives, as do we all really, and H.P. surely satisfies that need. I know too that J.K. Rowling originally intended that the books would be read by the same age children as Harry is in the book - Book 1 aged 10-11 and so on. (does a Grandma of %# years count?)My Granddaughter is 8yrs old but her 12 year old cousin has read all bar books 6 &7 and she thinks she can too. I'm sure if she finds them hard to understand then she will stop reading them. I'm happy she's reading, she's happy to read H.P. & the Philosophers Stone. All is well!

Review title: Harry Potter And The Philosopher's Stone, Kindle Copy
Review: So, as a blind person, I've got both narrations of the Harry Potter books so why spend money on the Kindle copies?  Well, I think the answer to that is that I just love returning to join Harry and his friends in the wizarding world and with having access to Kindle through Alexa I felt I might as well go right ahead and purchase them on Kindle.I just love this book right from the start and even though it isn't as exciting and edge of your seat as the other books are, yet there is that excitement you feel along with Harry in Chapter 4 when Hagrid turns up in the shack during the storm to give him the good news and I don't think any Harry Potter fan could ever fail to feel the excitement along with Harry as he and Hagrid go to Diagon Alley and he buys his books and other material he'll need for his time at Hogwarts.  I love it when his vault at Gringots is opened and he sees all the money his parents have left him.  I love the background we get to the Dursleys in the first chapter and the description of the day which eventually leads to his arrival at Privet Drive.  As we read this book, we need to be aware how little Harry knows and we get an idea of how he's feeling as he awaits his sorting on his arrival at the school.  As the Dursleys fight a losing battle when the letters start coming (and increasing with each delivery, ending with about a hundred at the hotel, you just know that, even though they're eventually in a place where Uncle Vernon's certain they won't be disturbed, that by hook or by crook Dumbledore will eventually get him to Hogwarts.  As he tells Mrs Cole in Book 6, they'll be taking Tom Riddle away whatever.  So Harry begins this roller coaster adventure throughout the seven books and he will not only need his friends but all the magical training he can get, especially in Defence against the dark arts which will be important as he must face the wizard who has not only attempted to kill him but has eluded capture by the Ministry of Magic.

i always knew this book would be one I loved, but for some reason never read it.  So it was one of those books I ended up knowing about, and saw the movie for but hadn't read.Finally I got around to read it and found it was far better than I imagined. Completely different to the impression I had in my head about it.I am so late to the party there is little I can say about it, but if you are like me and still at the thinking about it stage then buy this book and you wont be disappointed.

I really liked this book. It's about a boy who lives in a broom cupboard at his uncle's house and who hilariously ends up at a wizard-school!.. you can't make this up. It's full of weird terms and magical jargon which makes it sometimes hard to read. Yet it has a nice plot. But i'm not going to spoil more of the story here - read it yourself.They should make a movie about this! In fact, the story lends itself very well for a sequel.

This book is a fabulous start to the series, and it got me really hooked! The story is about a young boy named Harry, whose wizard parents died after an evil wizard killed them. Unbeknown to Harry he was going to be a wizard as after the death of his parents he lived with his aunt and uncle, the meanest people who you could imagine, the opposite to his parents. This book tells you about his magical adventures at Hogwarts, a school for witches and wizards.I loved this book as it makes you imagine what it would be like to have that experience of being at Hogwarts, it really takes you away into a magical world. The highlight for me was the fantastic setting of Hogwarts, it seemed so real but as I‚Äôve now seen the film it was an even clearer picture. The only negative point for me about this book was that I couldn‚Äôt put it down! The great thing about the book is it allows children to escape into a new world of magic and adventure . I would recommend this book to people aged 9 - 99!I guarantee it will take you into a magical world.

Review title: Best Book for Children and Adults.
Review: Bought Philosophers Stone for my young cousin  it obviously I've read and reread it myself over the years. Shes 8 this year and reading is her absolute favourite thing so I thought this would be a good time to introduce HP. I cannot recommend the book enough for adults and children alike. It's a great book to get children interested in other books, even if you read them this and they start to read the others themselves. Just don't let them watch the films first - the books are so much better!

It seems just about everyone I know has read this series. Having watched the movies and finding them enjoyable if slightly frustrating I decided it was time to dive in to the books. Though brief (finished this first book in one sitting) it did seemingly  cast a little bit of magic on me. I did feel some of the world building was a little on the light side, but reminded myself that as a child friendly read much more would have possibly put the original target audience off. I look forward to picking up the next book in the series.

Review title: The most loved, magical book you could ever read!
Review: I've read this series to my son so many times (he's a huge HP fan just like me!) I love how the friendship between Harry, Hermione and Ron grows throughout the series and the magical adventure they take us on. There are a lot of interesting and fun characters to meet throughout the story and we all need a Dumbledore in our life. Hogwarts is a school that everyone wants to attend. This book has everything, a fabulous plot, intriguing characters, a world full of magic and a whole lot of excitement that will have you binge reading ... a must read for all ages!

As a teenager growing up around the same age as Harry Potter did in the films (when each of them came out), I found the stories both in the films and books (once I got round to reading them) highly imaginative, relatable in many ways and compelling reading. The books of course have a great deal more story and background information than the films could ever include, which makes the books even more enjoyable to read again and again. Like the characters, the books mature over the series and change from being predominantly for children to young adults; but the popularity of these books have shown how they can be enjoyed by people of all ages.

Review title: A Great Children's Book Which I Sure Will Be A Classic
Review: I think I was about 23 when this first came out. There was a lot of hype about it and I got the chance to scan the first few pages of somebody else's book and saw it as a children's book and it wasn't for me.Some years later on I've got children of my own. They're nearly seven and although they're not quite of the ability to read it themselves I read it to them at bed time and they love it. We just read a few pages every night and stop at a point that leaves them inquisitive as to what happens next.It's not comparable to Tolkien or Pratchett and I don't think it's supposed to be. It's a simple 200 page children's book about a little boy who is a wizard and goes to wizard school.My children love it. I've heard it gets a bit more sinister as the series goes on but we'll cross that bridge when we come to it. This first one is exciting and involving for them and only occasionally does a word need explaining to them.If J. K. Rowling is heralded as the new Enid Blighton I think is rightly so. I think she written something that captures children's imagination and encourage a generation to read books and that's no bad thing.

Review title: a touch of nostalgia to treasure
Review: Way back when we started to read Harry Potter to our children, the first book being borrowed from the Library without knowing a huge amount about it.  We were hooked from page one and over the years it became somewhat of an event for the whole family eagerly awaiting the next book in the series to read about the magical world of Harry Potter and his chums.  The books are so much better than the films and highly recommended even if you have seen the films.  Particularly, the early books that were somewhat less dark and a bit more fun.  The level of detail that goes into making this parallel world believeable is the biggest talent of all for J K Rowling.  What a mind to have been able to think up the rules of Quidditch and all of the wonderful spells.  My daughter was seven with the original Library copy of the Philospher's Stone, we took turns in reading a page each.  My secret was that I used to leave her room at night only to go to bed and read on alone as I could not wait to see what happened next!  So back to present day and a gift for a rather cool teenager, what better than the hardback version of the only book in the series that we did not actually own a copy of.  Amongst all the designer clothes, CD's and perfume in the Christmas stocking this bought the biggest smile along with the Harry Potter Lego!  The timeless Mr Potter brings out the inner child in all of us.

Review title: Harry is no normal boy... HE'S A WIZARD!
Review: Harry Potter and the philosophers stone.By JK RowlingAn amazing tale of a boy, Harry Potter. He lives in a house with his nasty auntie, uncle and cousin. Harry is no normal boy... HE'S A WIZARD!This is a story about his first year at his new school with his two new friends. Learning spectacular spells, how to make potions and coming face to face with his immortal enemy.I really loved this book, it was amazing.

Purchased for daughters birthday. She has watched the films and now wanted to read the books! So she decided to purchase this with her birthday money. Fantastic read for an 8 year old and her comment is it‚Äôs much better than the film as the film missed too much out! Great for ages 8+

Review title: I really recommend  it  to everybody, doesn't matter how old you are!!
Review: As always amazon delivered the item on time, great service!!I'm 26 and I never though of reading Harry Potter, then recently i watched an interview with J.K.Rowling and with my surprise she explained how hard  her life was before becoming so famous. Then she spoke about Harry with so much passion as a mother would talk about her child. So I though that even though I am a bit old for this kind of reading I would give it a try. Well reading the book I felt as the characters were almost real, they surely are for Mrs. Rowling and she couldn't have written this book better. I was totally hooked. I really recommend  it  to everybody, doesn't matter how old you are!!

Having bought this for my elder son, I found myself buying them again for my younger sons 10th birthday so that he had his own copy.  The cover is much updated and has a lovely feel to it.  Yes, that does sound as strange as it reads but I do judge a cover on its design and feel.  He hasn't read it or the others (I bought the first 3) but was delighted to have his own copies.  Based on the first 3 books I think I will buy the remaining books for his Christmas so that he has the full set in this design.

Wasn‚Äôt sure would be my sort book. But read in few days, enjoyable, will probably try book 2. I used to only read biographies but started reading crime novels. Tried Harry Potter because so popular and reviews high wide age group.

I'm in my twenties and Harry Potter has been my favourite story for as long as I can remember. Being a huge potter-head, I decided to buy the children's edition, as it has larger font and each chapter is decorated with stars. They also feature a map of Hogwarts, drawn in an illustrative style, which adds more charm to it.High quality paper and lovely matter cover with bright gold lettering.Excellent read for kids and adults alike!Thank you JK Rowling for making my childhood magical.

I have ordered a few pre-owned books from various places and have had a few disappointments when it comes to quality - even when something has been sold as good or very good. This book I received was excellent quality so I am very pleased

My seven year old grandson gallops through Tom Gates, Billy Bonkers, Dirty Bertie and Astrosaurs books.Wanting to stretch him a bit and after discussion with his mother, started him on David Walliams and he has devoured the whole lot.After further discussions, I got this for him and....he galloped through it, although he did have to ask for help with a small number of words and concepts - he tells me it is brilliant.HP 2 is on order and, when we have finished the HP series, I suppose it will have to be Dostoevsky, Zola or Kafka.

Review title: Excellent book at a bargain price!

I think the price for this book is excellent and I would have expected it to cost more than it did.  I am sure I will be back to purchase the next book in the series for him once hes completed reading this once.  would recommend to others.

She does not put a lot of description but the book is still great.

Review title: Books and film on equal ratings.
Review: I am now around 3/4 of the way through the book and it is as good as I hoped it would be. Having watched all the movies I wanted to read the books to just pad out the storylines a bit more, as I know it is impossible to put every detail into a film. The films have kept to the main element of the book and I hope all the rest will be as good.

What to say about this book that hasn‚Äôt been said before? The pages felt really nice in my fingers and it had that nice new book glue smell (my inner Charlie Kelly was very happy indeed). The cover was smooth and soft, and the whole book was manufactured to a high standard which I was very impressed with. I liked the pictures on the front, they were nice. Good size book, fit nicely in my bag. Would recommend to a friend

Review title: I feel like I've missed out on something so important that only ...
Review: I've never read the Harry Potter series as a Child. I know, what a crime! I feel like I've missed out on something so important that only kids who've read the books can understand. I am now 23 years old and have just started reading the books (I was always a massive fan of the movies). I feel like I've been let in on this wonderful secret, and it's amazing! It really does open your imagination, even as an adult. I'm delighted that I decided to read the first one, and I'm so happy that 7 books exist, because I sense a magical summer is ahead of me.

Review title: THE FIRST BOOK IN THE MOST MAGICAL SERIES EVER WRITTEN!
Review: HARRY POTTER AND THE PHILOSOPHER'S STONE is the first book in the HARRY POTTER series, which are in my opinion the best books ever written. This one, funny, dark and very clever, begins Harry's journey and introduces many brilliant, original and memorable characters. The storyline was so gripping and engaging that i read the book in just a few days. It is reasonably short (unlike the other ones which are just as good if not better) so young children wont get bored, but even if it was over 1,000 pages i would never get bored. Everyone has heard of this series and most people love these books, and this one is the one that started it all. A magical book! ENCHANTING! 10/10!
There's almost no point reviewing this as pretty much everyone knows all there is to know, but my seven-year-old is reading it avidly and loving every minute!

It will remain a 'classic' to Potterheads, but if you want an up to date version, and a fun, fast-moving read, then try Barry Potter: Phil Osafa's Stoned.

I envy him that he is embarking upon this magical journey but will enjoy watching him do so! Next for induction the great nephews and nieces.

Review title: Jo does a marvellous job of crafting an intricate story that sets a great ground for the rest of the series
Review: I pre-ordered this book in early August, eagerly anticipating September 1st when it would arrive on my doorstep. Low and behold, it arrived mid-afternoon is the standard Amazon cardboard packaging. Now, to say I'm a Harry Potter fan would be an understatement, so this was definitely a treat.The content is exactly the same as any other edition of Philosopher's Stone, which in itself is a magical story for all ages that follows a young, orphaned boy as he discovers that he is a wizard and attends his first year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry whilst forming lasting friendships and coming face-to-face with the very person who killed his parents. Jo does a marvellous job of crafting an intricate story that sets a great ground for the rest of the series.John Duddle does a fantastic job of the new artwork which brings a new face to the British version of the books, but in my opinion, the American covers by Kazu Kibuishi, published my Scholastic are a little bit nicer.Overall, this is a great book for all ages that introduces you to the magical world of Harry Potter that will leave you enchanted by the wizarding world.

Star Wars, meets Wizards and spells ala Terry Pratchet's earlier works, meets Charlie and the Chocolate Factorty.  Just some of the comparisons I had.  Yes the book is as good as the hype, the kids will love it, if they  can get it off dad first.  The book is beautifully crafed and many aspects  of childhood covered.  The beauty of the book is that you start to wonder  who out in the wide world are "Muggles" and who are the magic  beings.  Read the book to find out more.  Beware one taste and you will be  dying for more of young Mr Potter and his wizarding career.  First class,  Rowling is up there with Dahl and Sheppherd, in those classic children  books which are just that little bit more.

If your kids normally argue and fight on car journeys then you should buy this audio book.  Since purchasing and then playing this set of C.D.s we have had two 200 mile journeys in blissful near silence.  The only time they talk is to remind us to put the next disc in.  Stephen Fry reads brilliantly.  I think they are entertained more by this than they are by the films.  Sometime we will have to find the cash for the next set of recordings.  And there is the only down side; they are a bit pricey.  But worth it!

Review title: It's a wonderful story that just absorbs you into a world that ...
Review: The book that introduced us all to the wonders that is Harry Potter. It's a wonderful story that just absorbs you into a world that we could only dream of being a part of. The enchanted version ibooks has is simply stunning and a definite for any collector. The images are gorgeous and really let you become a part of the story.The first story is slower than the others but it's the first book in a long series, we kind of expect that, don't we? Harry and the gang are truly a lovable clang - I love Ron the most and it's not just because we share a birthday. I also find myself loving the dynamics of the character that is Draco Malfoy. He will be a character I know I will grow to love beyond words. I am interested to see who I become more connected too... despite any birthday connections or house connections (considering I am a Slytherin)All in all, a joyous book. One I cannot wait to share with the kids in my life and for generations to come

Dar√ºber hinaus ist das gesprochene Englisch sehr zug√§nglich, sodass sich das H√∂rbuch theoretisch auch zum √úben der englischen Sprache bzw. f√ºr nicht so sprachsichere Zuh√∂rer eignet. Review title: The book I fell in love with.
Review: I‚Äôll never forget the day I first began Harry Potter And The Philosopher‚Äôs Stone. I believe I can say, with out hesitation, that it changed my life. My friend had received it for her birthday, and she suggested we give it a try. I admit I was curious, but I was not expecting anything spectacular. After all, I was an adult, and these books were for children, right? I‚Äôve never been so wrong in my life. From the start, I was entranced. I had no idea where the story was going, but JK Rowling had me hooked. I lapped it up. I kept wanting more, and by the end, I knew I‚Äôd stumbled on to something wondrous. A series that was quite literally addictive. I adored this eleven year old boy, who had captured my heart from the time he was left wrapped in a blanket on his aunt and uncle‚Äôs doorstep. My imagination was caught from the moment the tall wizard appeared on a normal suburban street, put out the street lamps, and began sucking on a Sherbet Lemon. This book has seen me through good times and bad. It‚Äôs been my friend in unfamiliar places, and comforted me when I was sick. What could‚Äôve been such a simplistic idea (a boy discovering he‚Äôs a wizard and being spirited off to magic school) turned out to have so much more to it. Humour, originality, mystery, and above all, plenty of magic. It helped me rediscover books from my childhood that I‚Äôd loved, and has lead to what I suspect will be a life long love of fantasy literature. I am now a firm Quidditch fan, and I think Harry‚Äôs sighting of his dead parents in a magic mirror is one of the most moving and poignant scenes I‚Äôve ever read. And let‚Äôs not forget of course, the truly wonderful narration of Stephen Fry. He really should get an Oscar for all his character portrayals. I‚Äôve never known anyone put so much heart in to what they read. A magical beginning to a magical series.

Review title: The Start of an Excellent Book Series
Review: The first book is really fantastic, like all six of her books. I remember the first book I ever read was book 4 (Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire). I started reading it, but I found the first chapter boring. I gave up. I'm never really in a reading mood and I know I should be, because everybody needs to read and exercise their brain.Anyway not long after, during an english lesson, where we spent the whole lesson reading in silence, I noticed one of my mates was reading one of the Harry Potter books. I remember it was book 3 (Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban). I remember asking him if the book was good. He said that it was briliant. Don't laugh but this somehow motivated me to read the 4th book I had at home. I started reading it, ignoring how boring I found the first chapter. Near towards the end of the first chapter, I got hooked onto it. I found myself reading it constantly, getting more and more interested. I found the book fantastic. I couldn't believe I had never read it sooner. I had to read the other three (book 5 wasn't out yet).Anyway the first book is a really good book. No it's more than really good. It's excellent. If you watched the film, then you must read the book. Because believe me when I say that the book is better than the film.It's about a boy (we know his name), who's spent 10 miserable years with his reltives the Dursley family. His uncle Vernon is always jumping down his throught, his aunt Petunia is always nasty, they both see him as filth and his cousin Dudley (about the same age) is always bullying poor Harry. Harry learns on his 11th birthday that he is a wizard. He's not just a wizard, but in the wizard world he's famous.His mum and dad were murdered by the most evil wizard of all time, Voldemort. After killing James and Lily Potter (Harry's parents) he attempted to kill Harry himself. Somehow Harry survived it, left with a permanent lightning shaped scar on his forehead. This somehow defeated Voldemort and Harry was only a baby.He goes to Hogwarts school of witchcraft and wizardry, where he trains to be a wizard. He befriends a boy and a girl (Ron Weasley and Hermoine Granger). Ron is a really nice, loyal person and Hermoine is an annoying boffin, who's always siding with the teachers (the last person to trust if you were attempting to break school rules). Harry also makes his first enemy (Draco Malfoy; a nasty Slytherin kid. All the nasty ones end up in Slytherin House). Harry, Ron and Hermoine end up in Gryffindor house. The other two are Hufflepuff and Ravenclaw.Soon Harry and his friends discover that Dumbledore's got something really valuable within Hogwarts (well protected) and someone (their No 1 suspect professor Snape; potions teacher who is nasty to the Gryffindors and is also head of Slytherin).This book is definetely worth reading and buying. Rowling did a fantastic job with this book. Not just the way it was written OR the story, but how she made the wizard life. Their lives are like ours, but with the use of magic. They have a ministry of magic for instance(the wizard govenment), wizard shops and their own sport Quiditch.That I found brilliant. There are Seven players on each team, that fly on broomsticks and there is four balls (a quaffle, two bludgers and a golden snitch) Two beaters hit the bludgers, protecting their team as the bludgers zoom around the pitch, trying to injure the players. Three chasers handle the quaffle and try to put it through one of the three hoops at the end of the pitch. The keeper defends them and the seeker catches the snitch, ending the game and awarding his/her team 150 points. The game was really well designed.The schools are similar to secondry schools. At secondry schools pupils have different subjects in different classrooms, with differnt teachers. The classrooms are designed for that subject. Hogwarts is the same, but with wizard subjects (charms, potions, etc). It's a well written book, inteligently done. One of the best books I've ever read. There's no chance in hell you'll regret getting this.

Review title: Great book, but for die-hard Potter fans only!
Review: This is a great book for die-hard Harry Potter fans!But, before I go to far, there are a couple of important differences between this deluxe slipcase edition, and the cheaper, non-slipcase edition. First of all the deluxe version is physically larger than the regular illustrated version. Slipcase aside, the book itself is about 2 inches taller and about 2 inches wider. Overall, the deluxe version is about 13 inches tall and approximately 11 inches wide, which may make it a tougher fit on some people's book shelves. Also, the deluxe version is printed in Italy, whereas the regular illustrated version is printed in China. Although I didn't do too many side-by-side comparisons of each book, it does seem like the illustrations in the deluxe version are much brighter than the cheaper version printed in China -go figure.I should also point out that I purchased my deluxe version through BWBCanada and the book did not arrive in shrink-wrap. So, if any of you are buying this for collecting purposes keep that in mind. However, the price was WAY better than Amazon's price, the book arrived on time, and there were no additional fees, import fees, or duty. I only paid what was charged during the Amazon check-out procedure, and when I picked this parcel up at the post office, I did not have to pay anything extra.Lastly, I'll say it again, this book is for die-hard Harry Potter fans only. The deluxe slipcase edition is very expensive and really doesn't offer that much above the regular illustrated version.Update:I would also like to add that the customer service at BWBCanada is fantastic. I had quite a few questions that needed to be answered before I felt comfortable ordering this book from this company and every time I sent an e-mail to BWBCanada, the customer service representative answered all my questions in each e-mail. This was my first time ordering a book from overseas (UK) and I had a lot of questions about duty, import fees etc. and they did a fantastic job of reassuring me before I placed my order. I would definitely feel comfortable ordering from them again.

Almost pointless for me to even review this book with the 4,000+ reviews so far but since it is my favourite series I feel I must.I think the thing that is so great about this series is that even though it is a VERY easy read, there is such an amazing description of this other world that you can actually get lost in it. It is so unlike our ordinary lives but the characters are so easily relatable that you can actually believe this world could be real.This book I think saved my life. I read it at a time when I was so depressed and had almost given up completely. I picked up The Sorcerer's Stone on sale to see what the hype was about. I couldn't put it down. There were five books out at the time and so bought the other four right away. And now every time I start to feel a little down I read Harry Potter and it picks me right up and takes me away from my own problems. I have since recruited 3 Potter fans. It's a shame the series ended and I hope J.K. is working on something else that is equally amazing.

This fiction book was published in1997. There are 332 pages. To me , it was pretty short as I can read twice the number of pages in 2 or 3 days, not more!It takes place in different places: Number 4 Privet Drive, platform 9 and three quarters at King‚Äôs Cross Station, Diagon Alley and at Hogwarts, school of witchcraft and wizardry. The different settings make the story interesting as J. K .Rowling gives a very good description of all the places, so that you really see them in your head. The book is set during modern times, so today.Harry Potter is the main character in all 7 stories. He turns 11 in this book. His parents are dead because of a wizard, Voldemort, also called the Dark Lord, or You-Know-Who, He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named, as people are so afraid of him. Harry is famous because he survived Voldemort‚Äôs attack on him and parents. Since he had almost no family left, he went to live with his Aunt and Uncle Dursley and cousin .They hate him and treat him badly. They don‚Äôt tell Harry he is a wizard, so Harry thinks he will be living with the Durleys for the rest of his life until he is big enough to have a house all to himself. He is my favorite character as he is very brave and friendly.Other characters:Ron Weasly is Harry‚Äôs best friend and very scared of spiders.Hermione Granger is also Harry‚Äôs best friend and knows a lot about magic. She always gets good marks in every topic.This is a story about courage, faith, friendship and loyalty.It showed me the importance of having friends and always standing up for the things you think are important.Overall, I thought this was a great book because you can really imagine what it is like to be a witch or a wizard. It is one of my all- time favorites, and I can‚Äôt wait to go on to the 6th, as I am reading the 5th right now but prefer this one!I loved all the adventures, magic, meeting new people‚Ä¶I didn‚Äôt care for the part where Harry was arguing with Prof. Quirell , as the dialogue went on for a long time .The ending made me feel good as I had finished a super book.I think that people of all ages can read this book. I don‚Äôt recommend it for smaller children as even I had some nightmares that were horrible.I would give this book 4 and a half stars out of 5, as sometimes there was too much dialogue (like with Prof.Quirell which I found hard to understand).Even so, this book is one of my top 5 favorites.Happy reading!P.T.G.

Read as an adult.One of the best books that I have read. I like that it's in plain English, I'm not impressed by the use of overly flowery words that confuse, especially where a simpler word would be enough. Fortunately this book is an easy read in that sense. Lots of characters, plenty going on in the story, and while it's part of a series, you do get answers before and by the time that you have finished the book. Some surprises and a sprinkling of humour. I feel sorry for Harry at times, the things that he goes through. Hagrid is one of my favourite characters, I like that he is protective. I think that most people, child and adult, would like a giant like Hagrid looking out for them.When I recently decided to begin reading Harry Potter. At first I felt like I was late to the party or something like that. But then I realised that a good book isn't like that. It's not a trend or a fad, it doesn't matter if you're reading it for the first time, years after most others have.

Picked as a wild card while ordering multiple books, what a gem.It seems like many moons ago since I watched the first harry potter movie, in fact one of the only ones that I ever did as a child and then didn't return to the series again since reading this book. As I read through it's pages I recalled endless amounts of memories from the film and how it went, it all fits in to place and makes for a very good read.The book length isn't to long nor to short, if you're planning to read them one by one as I was order number two in the series alongside just so that you don't finish the first and find yourself waiting for a delivery to continue the series.This book, the first in the series, is a very exciting and well put together introduction of all of the characters at Hogwarts and their jernouy on their first term. I find it brilliant that J.K. Rowling wrote Harry from a regular muggle to a wizard as it allows the reader to understand the wizardry world as Harry's learning it, to write it in any other way would have been hard to understand, a fine example of the brilliance of J.K. Rowling's writing in this series.The only problem with this book, as written in the book, is that you can't put it down. I decided to drag out the read over days as I like to have the feeling of something to go back to or wake up to and enjoy rather than everything else I do, I want to enjoy my time spent reading and this book certainly allows for that. Each chapter sets of where the last one left and there's no needing to remind yourself of the story before reading again, it all comes flooding back without trouble.I remember the original books and their designs, I think someone I know may still have them stored away somewhere but I defiantly like the look of the newer designed front covers, from the lightning strike in the o of the book title to the general coloring of the book and the feel of the cover I couldn't stop looking at it when I first got it delivered, something about the book draws me in.I have the second book on my bookshelf reading and waiting for the time next I decide to continue with the series, wanting to know more about this world and their adventures I'm sure that all be soon enough.On the whole I hadn't had an interest in the Harry Potter series since a kid as explained but reading this book has made me realize what a gem of a read I've been missing. I appreciate this isn't the newest book in existence and to many they've probably read the last book and watched the last film and it's all over but even then I can imagine that this series is worth a re-read for someone who has the time. So, on the whole, if you're thinking about buying it as I did as something to dive into and see if you do or don't like, DO IT, there's no regret to be had, and at the prices that Amazon are able to offer the paperback version for I can't believe the quality for so little money.Enjoy.

And yet, I feel compelled to type them.As a parent:Best, I feel, for kids starting at around age ten.  Not because a seven year old couldn't handle it, but because once you start a kid on this series, they will voraciously consume them all without stopping.  Ideally I think a young reader should roughly be the same age as Harry in each book, because I think that was the author's intent, as the later books are more mature in theme and more complex in plot.As a Reader:I enjoy the wordplay and clever allusions and the rich, colorful, yet never verbose descriptions of the Wizarding World, but in terms of story and tone, I'm too old for this book.  If you've never read Harry Potter, don't be surprised if you feel this way while reading the first few books (if you make it that far).  For me, the series took off at around book four.As a Consumer:The Bloomsbury hardcover is well made and I enjoy the illustration on the cover.  It's worth noting that the book underneath the jacket looks exactly the same as the jacket itself; the same illustration adorns both.  If you're buying this as an adult and are assuming that underneath the jacket, there is a plain black or brown book that will not stand out on your grown-up bookshelf, think about looking for a different printing.  If you're American as I am (sorry for living) you've come to the right place; the American versions have different wording and even the title of the American version of this book is changed (Sorcerer's Stone).  Unforgivable.

Review title: Let's Take a Second Look at the Original Harry Potter Novel and See if It Still Upholds Well
Review: I have reread the first Harry Potter novel for the first time in about 10 years in this latest edition issued by Bloomsbury. Bloomsbury UK has reissued all the HP novels in beautiful new hardcover editions with beautiful dust jacket art by Jonny Duddle. (You can still find some of these in their respective first printings, so try that instead of feeling you need to shell out ¬£15,000 for a hardcover first edition of the original book.) These may be the best-looking of all the HP editions issued by Bloomsbury. Even the original covers for the US editions are not as good as these. But cover art aside, does Harry Potter stand up after a second go-through? Is the charm and excitement still there? After a second reading where I'm actually noticing more than I did the first time, I conclude, yes, Harry Potter and his adventures are still as charming as ever.What is the charm of Harry Potter? How does Rowling make it seem so effortless? Rowling used several storytelling devices to achieve her literary goals. Of course, on the forefront, is Harry Potter himself, a kind of loser kid at first glance, being imprisoned by a family of overweight and pompous nincompoops who might make the likes of the McFly's (from the "Back to the Future" films) seem as highly cultured as the Windsors. When I first read the Harry Potter books in the early 2000's, I felt the Dursley's were so disgustingly over-the-top I thought it was the one weakness of the novels. However, upon rereading, I see what Rowling was doing. The magic of Harry Potter is that she offers all these little dilemmas which Harry has to overcome, the first is navigating and then eventually escaping the mad clutches of the Dursley's.While, sure, the Dursley's are just about as crass a family as you'll ever read in children's literature, the Dursley's serve to keep pushing the story further. We know, of course, Harry will escape Vernon and Dudley but the narrative doesn't allow it to happen right away. Like a Beethoven symphony where we're waiting for the main theme to return in tutti fortissimo, we're waiting for Harry to overcome the Dursley's, and other similar situations which permeate much of the book, such as being placed into the right "house", learning the game of Quidditch, and the climactic ending where a kind of oversized chess match may mean life or death for Harry and his friends Ron and Hermione. And this is how the novel keeps us interested and desiring to read more. She doesn't offer the solutions and/or resolutions of the many dilemmas to end too quickly, and often the resolution is not exactly as expected but rather lead into the next problem. Only Rowling could dream up having the Dursley's move to a shack on an island just so Harry won't be able to receive copies of the letter inviting him to enroll at Hogwarts, School of Wizards and Wizardry. This is just one example of the many situations Harry faces during the course of the novel. In most books, especially children's books, there are maybe only one or two dilemmas a main character may face. Harry is constantly being pelted with them.Another aspect of the story, nearly as important, is the wonderful details which Rowling gives her readers. When we enter Diagon Alley along with Harry, she describes not only the many shops, but little tiny vignettes about the many people wandering through this first taste of the "magic world" as opposed to the "muggle" world. (I wish I wasn't a muggle!) Shops, shopkeepers and shoppers are all going about their business and Rowling tells us about them with just enough flair and detail we're interested in what we're seeing but not too much for it to become overdone. We always come back to Harry and Hagrid and why they're walking through Diagon Alley, which rings of London's Charing Cross Road, known for its bookshops, and Portobello Road, famous for its many antique and unusual shops.Harry Potter is almost a series of threaded vignettes which create a beautiful mosaic of storytelling at a phenomenal level. I have read few books of fantasy which have as much detail and depth as Harry Potter, with a bit of humour and a bit of darkness to keep the story well-balanced. J.R.R. Tolkien's the Hobbit comes to mind, as well as some of the Conan stories by Robert E. Howard. Rowling's Harry Potter books have just about everything: wonderful characters occupying an imagined world coupled with situations and plots to keep the reader interested in the seeming never-ending threads of story. On top of it, there is an underlying rhetorically theme.Before he learns who he really is, Harry Potter views himself as a loser kid who has nothing to offer, except his "moments" which cause him to be punished at the hands of the Dursley's. As the novel progresses, we learn he's something special, and part of the growth of the character is for him and his readers to discover the essence of his specialness. All children, and adults for that matter, should know, there is something which makes them unique and special, and part of the point of Harry Potter is to find that uniqueness, no matter how much other people may say otherwise. This is the true magic of Harry Potter, brought to us by a wizard, name of J.K. Rowling.

Review title: it really is to be enjoyed by all ages
Review: On the doorstep of Petunia and Vernon Dersley's house, a baby is waiting to be found.This baby is their nephew-Harry. He lives with his aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon and his cousin Dudley for eleven of his young years.Eleven years of tolerating his unpleasant, miserable life sleeping in the cupboard under the stairs, and being excluded from any family activity and thinking his parents died in a car accident which caused his lightening shaped scar on his forehead.After being rescued by Hagrid, the grounds keeper at Hogwarts school,Harry is invited to attend Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry,where his parent's had also spent their secondary school years.There he and his new friends find out about the evil one known to all around simply as 'You Know Who'.Hogwarts is a truly magical place. Hogwarts is a place that everybody wishes they could have gone to when they where eleven.Everyone that is anyone knows all about Harry, including the story about that interesting scar which Harry soon finds to be different to the one he has been led to believe. Hogwarts school is full of excitement,fantasy,mystery and friendship but Harry soon learns that there is also dark magic around him and enemies out to get him.This book has it all in spades including a three-headed dog, an attacking troll and a life sized, come to life chess board.Although this book is aimed at children, it really is to be enjoyed by all ages.I am totally enamoured by the first book in this series.I never read/watch anything when it is in the 'hype' and only recently watched the films in full, and in order. I am so glad I chose to read the books as well.I didn't want my imagination influenced by the films and am very glad to say, it wasn't.There is so much more to the book, much more detail that isn't in the film, and so the book was a whole new imaginative fantasy playing out in my mind.There is a huge amount of action packed into this amazing warm book. JK Rowling's writing style flows beautifully with crafty segments of humour scattered amongst it, that made me chuckle out loud.It's such an easy read and will appeal to children and grownups alike.I can't wait to rediscover the rest of this series and enter Hogwarts magical world once more.

Review title: Double review: Percy Jackson and the Lightning Thief (Rick Riordan) v. Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (Rowling)
Review: Double book review:Percy Jackson and the Lightning Thief (Rick Riordan)Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (Rowling)These are two very different books, aimed at roughly the same age bracket and both the start of a multiple volume series.To appreciate Harry Potter's book, one must have acquired a taste for quality writing, attention to detail and subtlety. To appreciate Percy Jackson's one only has to be able to read (a penchant for Greek mythology will also come in handily).Harry Potter is very well written, using a language that is simultaneously sophisticated and accessible to younger readers, a no mean feat. It is also the epitome of Britishness. There is a posh quality to it, an underlying assumption that readers must make an effort and have cultivated some sort of "good" literary taste. This is a book that goes well with shoegazing, faded wallpapers (the ones on actual walls, not the digital ones) and unbelievably bad sartorial choices. On the weak side (yes, I know it sounds odd, but I was being appreciative...) the book is slightly boring, doesn't have that much of a plot and sounds more like a diary than an adventure story.Percy Jackson is pure American entertainment industry fodder. It is competently written, but just so. It is imaginative and evolves at a regularly fast pace. It is a page turner (which Potter struggles to be) and is easily enjoyable. In a sense, and within the constraints of both books being roughly the same genre and for the same public, they are the opposite of each other. This is a book that goes well with Aerosmith, baseball caps and deluded world views.In the end both books get four stars but for very different reasons. Rick Riordan's book reaches the epitome of everything it sets itself to be, but its goal is one that, even if honed to perfection, is never worth more than four stars. Rowling's book aims higher but doesn't quite get there, so fails to earn the last star, which it could have earned had it managed to be more of a page turner without losing any of its present qualities.

Apr√®s avoir vu, revu et re revu les films, j'ai d√©cid√© de prolonger la magie en m'attaquant √† la lecture des aventures d'Harry Potter en fran√ßais... puis en anglais (si vous √™tes d√©butant dans la langue, n'h√©sitez pas, c'est un tr√®s bon ouvrage pour commencer). La couverture est magnifique, et l'histoire qu'elle renferme l'est tout autant. Et je vous l'assure, m√™me apr√®s tant de temps √† √™tre fascin√©e par l'univers d'HP, il n'en perd pas moins sa magie. This is a great book, filled with wonderful characters who are richly described and a pleasure to read about. One of the best things about this book is the way the characters develop, learning magic and the ways of the magical world as they, without immediately becoming super powerful and capable of doing anything; the characters, certainly the main trio of Harry, Ron and Hermione, complement each other well with each bringing something to the group.Along the way to the final confrontation there are laughs as well as some more serious scenes, all of which, though the book is intended for a younger audience, fit to be enjoyed by adults.I‚Äôve read Harry Potter and the Philosopher‚Äôs Stone more times than I can remember and continue to enjoy it, which I consider as important, if not more so, as how well the book‚Äôs written. In this case the book is both well written and enjoyable, and is likely to remain a favourite of mine for years to come.
